bibl.title: Twenty-fourth Biennial Report of the Superintendent of the Nebraska Hospital for the Insane

respStmt.name: OCLC Online Computer Library Center Inc.

p.seg: STATE OF NEBRASKA Twenty-fourth Biennial Report OF THE Superintendent OF THE Nebraska Hospital for the Insane LINCOLN, NEBRASKA To the Governor and the Board of Commissioners of State Institutions For the Biennium Ending November 30, 1918

306 THIRD BIENNIAL REPORT OF NEBRASKA HOSPITAL FOR THE INSANE, LINCOLN, NEBRASKA RESIDENT OFFICERS J. D. Case Superintendent H. A. Neweli Assistant Superintendent and Physician (Pathologist) R. H. Spraui.ing Staff Physician Alma Chapman Staff Physician J. R. Helms Steward Margaret Helms Matron Chloe A. Ogg Bookkeeper NON-RESIDENT Fredekk k A. Stuff Chaplain

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 307 NEBRASKA HOSPITAL FOR THE INSANE LINCOLN, NEBRASKA To his Excellency, Honorable Keith Xetille, Governor, and to the Honorable Members of the Board of Commit missionera of State Institutions. Henry Gerdes, Silas I. Holcomb, (turf Eugene 0. Mayfield, U( nth mi n : Since the beginning of the period covering the bien - niuni. beginning December 1, 191G, and ending November 30, 1918. there have been three superintendents in charge, namely: Dr. B. F. Williams, until January 1, 1918. Dr. L. B. Pilsbury, former first assistant physician, who was ap - pointed superintendent to succeed Dr. Williams and served until September 15, 1918, when he resigned to enter the Medical Reserve Corps of the army. Dr. J. D. Case was appointed superintendent September It;. 1918. During my superintendency, conditions have been unusual and at times serious, owing to the depletion in the ranks of the nurses and attendants, caused by the demands of the war. Added to this we have to cope with an epidemic of Spanish in - fluenza, which was a problem during the past summer and fall, causing much sickness among the employees, and add - ing a greater burden to the hospital physicians' duties. We are proud to state that forty of our employees have entered the service, eight in the Red Cross service as nurses and the remainder in various departments of the army and navy. Of this number three have given their lives for the cause. The Nebraska Hospital for the Insane at Lincoln came into existence in the year 1870. Since that time there has been a steady increase in the demands on the institution. The receiving district assigned to this institution com - prises the following fourteen counties in the southeast por - tion of the state: Cass, Douglas, Dodge, Gage, Johnson, Lancaster, Nemaha, Otoe, Pawnee, Richardson, Sarpy, Saun - ders. Saline and Seward.

308 THIRD BJKXNIAL REPORT OF The following reports and statistical tables comprise the twenty-fourth biennial report of the Nebraska Hospital for the Insane at Lincoln. This report embraces the period beginning December 1, 1916, and ending November 30, 1918. The population of this hospital on the first day of December, 1916, was 731 patients, 318 male and 413 female. There were admitted 233 male and 231 female patients dur - ing this biennial period. We have discharged from the hos - pital ninety male and 124 female patients. One hundred and five male and ninety female patients have died. There were in the hospital on the 30th day of November, 1918, 350 male and 436 female, or a total of 786 patients. The monthly average population of the hospital has been 759, and there has been a total of 1,195 patients under treatment during the biennial period. ACCOMPLISHMENTS During the biennial period special attention has been given to the development of the industrial department. An effort has been made to provide every patient with some occupation, such as needle work, basket making, rug weav - ing, and such household duties as are applicable to the various patients. Patients are made more contented and in many instances improve mentally by reason of having certain duties to perform. We regard industrial pursuits as very essential. The training school has made reasonable progress. Many of our nurses have gone forth into general work, some into army service, still others are completing their courses of instruction with our affiliated training school, the Cook County Hospital. AMUSEMENTS AND LIBRARY Various forms of amusements have been furnished for the benefit of our patients. Under the supervision of at - tendants those patients who wish to read are brought to the library, where they choose their own books for reading, and the librarian devotes a part of the library period read-

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 309 ing to the patients. The institution is furnished with twen - ty-seven of the best periodicals which are circulated in such a manner that they come into the hands of all who desire them. There are about 900 books of fiction, history, law, poems, encyclopedias, etc., in our library. Each Tuesday evening a motion picture show, which is greatly enjoyed by the patients, is given in the amuse - ment hall. Our Friday evening dance is always looked for - ward to by the inmates. KEMGIOl'S SERVICES Religious services are held each Sunday morning at 9:30. The institution choir, made up of persons connected with the institution, supplies the music. Dr. Frederick A. Stuff, our chaplain, conducts the services and we consider this hour of chapel most profitable. MEDICAL TREATMENT When a patient enters this institution a prompt diag - nosis is made of the case in order Liat a proper prognosis and treatment may be given. As an aid to diagnosis, seri - ological examinations are made and thus is being accom - plished to simplify our treatment. Epileptic patients are receiving great relief under proper institutional treatment, but much is to be learned by the medical profession regard - ing the cause and treatment of this disease. Excellent re - sults are being obtained from the hydrotherapy treatments and this institution is well equipped with the proper ap - paratus for this work. DIPSOMANIA A remarkable feature to be noted in the hospital records during the biennium, and possibly two years previous, is the gradual reduction in number of patients committed to be treated for drug and liquor habits. This undoubtedly is due to the laws governing the use of narcotics. One hundred ninety-eight patients were treated in 1915, 150 in 1916, seventy in 1917 and fifty in 1918. At this rate

310 THIRD BIENNIAL REPORT OF of decrease the admittance of a patient of this type will only be an occasional incident. DENTISTRY Many patients of the hospital come to us with tooth con - ditions very bad. Some develop tooth troubles while here. Bacteriological research has revealed that many physical difficulties are caused from tooth infections. The institu - tion has at its disposal a visiting dentist upon call. PLANS FOR THE FUTURE There is now under way a hospital building for men designed to accommodate 180 patients. This building will be ready for use before another year and will partly relieve the crowded condition existing now. The present hospital kitchen is small and rather poorly equipped. We hope to have a new one, bringing with it a new bakery and cold storage plant. A good-sized still which could furnish distilled water for making ice is also very much desired. The present boiler equipment is growing old and should be enlarged. Among other needs should be mentioned a new dairy barn. The dairy herd is poorly housed at present and there is no proper milk handling room. An ornamental iron fence in front replacing the barbed wire, and well distributed lights would add much to the campus. CONCLUSION I wish to thank the governor of Nebraska, and your honorable Board for the support given me during my period of superintendency, and to express my appreciation of the earnest efforts put forth by our staff and co-workers in the institution. Respectfully, J. D. Case, Super in ten den t. Lincoln, Nebraska, November 30, 1918.
